subject: Re: [junit] Is this the right way?
msgSnippet: Quick note, The provided url added a space (%20) to the address bar in my browser. Remove the space to view the article. andrew f On Wed, 28 Jul 2004 11:24:31
messageBody:
Quick note,

The provided url added a space (%20) to the address bar in my browser.
Remove the space to view the article.

andrew f

On Wed, 28 Jul 2004 11:24:31 -0400, J. B. Rainsberger
<jbrains@...> wrote:
> Waani Toss wrote:
> > I am able to compile my Factorial.java, but can not
> > run the test runner...am I even doing it the right
> > way? Can someone help...Thanks wanni!
>
> 1. Your code is not in a package. Put it in a package. JUnit's test
> runners do not properly work if your test is in the default package.
>
> > public static void main(String[] args) {
> >
> > int input = Integer.parseInt(args[0]);
> > double result = factorial(input);
> > System.out.println(result);
> > junit.textui.TestRunner.run(suite());
> >
> >
> > }
>
> 2. Delete main(). The test runners do not invoke your main.
>
> From the command line:
>
> java -cp junit.jar;yourCode.jar junit.textui.TestRunner
> >
> > public static Test suite() {
> >
> >
> > TestSuite suite = new
> > TestSuite(Factorial.class);
> >
> >
> > return suite;
> > }
>
> 3. Delete suite(). This is exactly what JUnit's test runners do by
> default, so this is superfluous.
>
> > public static double factorial(int x){
> > if (x<0)
> > return 0.0;
> > double fact = 1.0;
> > while (x>0) {
> > fact=fact*x;
> > x=x-1;
> > }
> > return fact;
> > }
> > }
>
> 4. You haven't written any tests here. Where are your methods that start
> with "test"?
>
> Please consider reading this excellent tutorial on JUnit. Build your
> factorial example as you go. I think you will find it very helpful.
>
> http://tinyurl.com/6hsl8
>
> Good luck.
> --
> J. B. Rainsberger,
> Diaspar Software Services
